comment: A very experienced Finnish grandmaster has been upholding this seldom continuation not without success for several last years. Frankly speaking, at home preparation I hadn't managed to find a way to gain a more or less tangible advantage for White.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 c5 3. cxd5 Nf6 4. Nf3 cxd4 5. Qxd4 Qxd5 6. Nc3 Qa5 7. b4
comment: Suddenly it turns out that black queen feels itself uncomfortably. Here my partner spent much time again and took an unhappy decision.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 c5 3. cxd5 Nf6 4. Nf3 cxd4 5. Qxd4 Qxd5 6. Nc3 Qa5 7. b4 e5 8. Qc4 Bxb4 9. Qxc8+ Ke7 10. Qxh8 Bxc3+ 11. Bd2 Ne4 12. Rd1
comment: White has defended all his weak points and is ready to start development - e3, Bd3 etc. Pay attention to the strong position of the queen on h8 - it holds black pieces of the queenside and doesn't let them to enter play.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 c5 3. cxd5 Nf6 4. Nf3 cxd4 5. Qxd4 Qxd5 6. Nc3 Qa5 7. b4 e5 8. Qc4 Bxb4 9. Qxc8+ Ke7 10. Qxh8 Bxc3+ 11. Bd2 Ne4 12. Rd1 Nc6 13. Qxa8 Qb6 14. e3 Nxd2 15. Nxd2
comment: Now White has no need moves like 15. Bd3

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 c5 3. cxd5 Nf6 4. Nf3 cxd4 5. Qxd4 Qxd5 6. Nc3 Qa5 7. b4 e5 8. Qc4 Bxb4 9. Qxc8+ Ke7 10. Qxh8 Bxc3+ 11. Bd2 Ne4 12. Rd1 Nc6 13. Qxa8 Qb6 14. e3 Nxd2 15. Nxd2 Bxd2+ 16. Rxd2 Qb1+ 17. Ke2 Qb5+ 18. Kf3 e4+ 19. Kg4 Qb4 20. Be2

1. d4 d5 2. c4 c5 3. cxd5 Nf6 4. Nf3 cxd4 5. Qxd4 Qxd5 6. Nc3 Qa5 7. b4 e5 8. Qc4 Bxb4 9. Qxc8+ Ke7 10. Qxh8 Bxc3+ 11. Bd2 Ne4 12. Rd1 Nc6 13. Qxa8 Qb6 14. e3 Nxd2 15. Nxd2 Bxd2+ 16. Rxd2 Qb1+ 17. Ke2 Qb5+ 18. Kf3 e4+ 19. Kg4 Qb4 20. Be2 Ne5+ 21. Kg3 Qxd2 22. Rd1 Qxe2 23. Qd8+
comment: Now it is the black king who appears in a mating net, and his white wis-a-wis takes the very active part in the former's capture.
